discussing today's topic will be wendy nather head of the advisory

amin cto of ping identity first we'll hear from wendy
thank you so much steve hi everybody i'm going to describe an experience that
probably a lot of you can identify with right about now it used to be that you had a strategic
plan organization you had your security program all planned out your projects and
suddenly you were notified that your flight is being diverted guess what instead of having this nice
rash guard swimsuit suddenly you're going to need a parka
and instead of those euros that you've been stocking up you found out now that you're going to need
some canadian dollars sorry about that you had some fabulous shoes that you were going to wear
on your vacation and all of a sudden you find out that you're going to need hiking boots
and instead of sun cream you're going to need wait what is that that that is a bear proof
cooler so you're probably asking yourself what in the world is going on
suddenly you need for all of your people remote connectivity for everybody not just your
admin users and not just a few remote access people you need it for everybody and this needs
to happen no matter what they're using and where they are and without relying on physical access
or verification this is something that we've always kind of assumed was available you could go
into the office and get your id or pick up a token or whatever you can't do that anymore
and in the meanwhile the attackers are sniffing hungrily at all of the the tents around you so
what does this mean guess what welcome to zero trust land
now by the way i know a lot of you are more familiar with the older version of fantasy island but
i kind of like this 90s version because i think malcolm mcdowell looks a little bit more sinister than ricardo montalban did
and it is a little bit scary so guess what surprise you're going to zero trust
land zero trust land is where the risk is greater because your attack surface has suddenly
just increased by a whole lot there are fewer viable options like i mentioned before you
can't rely on physical access or proximity to be able to do some of the things that
you needed to do supply chains are breaking down i don't know if
you've tried to get a new laptop these days but i know a lot of organizations are having trouble getting the kit that their employees
need the timeline and the future are unknown this is not like a natural disaster
where a hurricane passes through we know it's going to be done this is something where
we don't know how long this is going to go on what's going to happen what other things might pop up to complicate it
and you remember the old joke about the hikers and and the hiker says i don't have to
outrun the bear i just have to outrun the other hiker i'm here to tell you that that's not the
case anymore thanks to automation in attacks there is more than enough
bear to go around sorry about that so what is zero trust anyway it has
actually been around as a concept for a long time almost 20 years ago now the jericho
forum a bunch of financial institution cisos in the uk came together and talked about what they
called deparametrization and as you can tell deprimatorization is
such a hard word to say it's so long it doesn't even fit on this slide on one line so that's my theory as to
why it never really caught on but they did talk about the concept of treating everything as if it were
exposed to the open internet and securing it accordingly around about 2009 john kinderwag when he
was an analyst at forester started describing it as a zero trust model
and that's the term that kind of stuck now google started implementing this
internally and it took them several years and hundreds of engineers but they have come out in the meantime
with a great series of white papers in case you haven't read them i think there are seven or eight of them now
describing how they implemented it and they called their concept beyond corp so
there are so many different terms for zero trust and i know a lot of people don't
necessarily like this term a lot of csos feel as though this is talking about
not being able to trust your employees and let's face it you have to trust them to a certain extent so they can get
their work done so you can call it what you want actually my favorite new term that i
learned recently is from a book by chase cunningham who is the
um principal analyst at forrester these days who is champion championing zero trust except in his
book here he calls it edge and entity security and i find that that's a lot more
palatable to a lot of people and it makes sense because this is how we're adapting
no matter what you call it maybe there's a way we can agree on basic first principles how about let's
just agree that you shouldn't trust something just because it's on the inside of your firewall
we've seen a lot of breaches where that led to a problem whether it's there's a case
a really good one that was written up in by the state of colorado where they
suffered a breach because a developer set up a cloud instance
outside and it was only supposed to be temporary so they didn't really secure it and
it took after about 40 000 brute force attacks the attacker managed to guess the admin
password and the problem is this instance was joined to the internal domain
at the colorado department of transportation so in in other words it was trusted and
that's how the problem started it led to a big ransomware attack as i mentioned they they wrote it
up really well you can find their public papers on this so if you can't trust something just
because it's on the inside of your firewall what do we do now i'm going to propose that whatever you
want to call the new perimeter it's really any place where you make an access control decision
so this access control decision might still be made on the network layer it might still be
at the firewall but it could be other places too it could be at the operating system layer
at the middleware layer at the application layer it actually might be several of those
things because you don't want to rely on just one thing so if the perimeter is any place where
you make an access control decision what is this going to look like
i'm going to use my favorite analogy here if you come up with a better one let me know but this seems to resonate a lot with
with my sales people i don't know why let's pretend that you're in a club and
there's a bouncer at the door and the bouncer is the firewall and the bouncer's letting people in and
you're the bartender and someone comes up to you and says i want to access your resource i want to
get a drink what you say to them is look i don't care why the bouncer let you in if you
want to access my resource you're going to have to show me some id because that's my access policy
so you're putting the policies right up as close as you can to the point of
access and you're not relying on other points of access
and decision makers to make the whole access decision for you because who knows why
the bouncer is letting people in or maybe you're a bouncer or you're a
bartender and your bar is out on the patio and nobody ever sees the bouncer that's
kind of what like sass is isn't it so you want to enforce your policies as
close as possible to the point of access and they are going to vary based on the criticality of the resource
that you're guarding so like i said let me know if this analogy works for you i find
it's a great way to describe to people in short form how the principle
is different now what controls are we using with this model a lot of them sound very
familiar we talk about defined roles and segmentation which is really
you know a version of least privilege we talk a lot about multi-factor authentication
we emphasize endpoint security even more than we used to and we talk about continuous monitoring
well some people talk about continuous monitoring i know that this is a thing that for example
gartner describes with their car to model i don't know personally of many
organizations that have the people to do real continuous monitoring at the
logging depth that they need to uh just because this is very hard to do but let's let's leave that for now let's
just say you monitor a lot how's that so what's the difference now
a lot of these principles have been around like least privilege the difference is sometimes technology
so for example we are describing now micro segmentation
at the network layer with new technology you'll find a lot of products out there that are offering that
but another really interesting concept point which again i believe an analyst at gartner first
mentioned is the concept of authenticating first before you connect
in other words you don't let somebody just run wild over your network and look for a
place where they can authenticate they've got to authenticate before they can even see the rest of the network
and so that is a difference now that we are following with zero trust
with multi-factor authentication again we've had that for a really long time
i found an old rsa hard token in my garage from 25 years ago it's been around what's the
difference first of all we're going to do it for everybody this time
it it shouldn't just be for administrative users other types of privileged users or for
remote users it needs to be for everybody because attackers are going after any set of credentials
that they can even if they don't have access to very much and then they're going to try to
see if they can escalate their privileges and move laterally within the network so
it's got to be for everybody across the board we need more factors and more factors
are available now and more flexibility we need to be able to help people who cannot get a cellular signal
in a particular building or for example somebody came to me and asked me
how would you do two-factor authentication in a sterile operating room which is a really
interesting problem if you can't just sterilize a hard token you can't tattoo a qr code on the back of
somebody's neck you can't use retinal scans because they're wearing safety goggles you know all of that face
id is not working as well when you're wearing a mask we have to and we are putting in more factors
but one of the important things is yes sometimes you still have to rely
on an ip address or a mac address as part of the authentication but it
shouldn't be the only thing that you rely on anymore
another difference in endpoint security especially now is that you can't assume
that the device is corporate owned and managed there are a lot of organizations who could not get enough
equipment for their people to work remotely and just said look use whatever you've got
um you have to be able to check at every authentication
not just once you can't just register an end point and say okay we're good now
uh you've got to check and see who's using it and and you may need to look at where it
is especially if you have regulatory uh issues that you need to comply with
that are based on geolocation but what you can do even if you can't
manage the device is you can make the access contingent on compliance and by this i
mean now we do have the ability to look at the security state of an endpoint even if we're not
managing it even if we've never seen it before and say look you can do what you want with
your laptop on your own time but if you want to access our resources you're going to have to meet certain
security requirements you've got to have your software up to date you've got to
use disk encryption you have to have lock screen enabled that sort of thing so it's more of a
collaborative position that the org can be at now and say to the users we can't always
control what you're using but we do enforce policies on the security state
of that and you're going to have to meet them if you want to access our resources
the other cool thing that really helps is being able to bind the user directly to
so you can't say that any user with the right credentials can use any of the corporate devices they have
to use that assigned device so if you put all these three things together or four
things you know a number of factors together if you say that somebody has to have the right
credentials and they have multi-factor authentication let's say it's an app on a phone and
they have to be using the right laptop it's no longer the case that an attacker can silently steal credentials and then
come in from someplace else they would have to steal the particular phone that was using that app
they would have to steal the laptop and when hardware starts to go missing people start to notice so it makes it
much much harder for the to get in once you can do this sort of thing with endpoint security
continuous monitoring again not just at every authentication time but there's a
lot of work being done with behavioral analytics you may see a user who was authenticated
properly doing something with resources that they're not supposed
to be doing either you made a mistake when you authenticated them and you thought it was really them and it wasn't
or it's an insider threat but either way you're going to look at their behavior and then you might want to step up the
authentication you might want to say look this is looking kind of funny we're just
going to ask you for some other things now to make sure that you really are who you say you are
so that option of doing authentication at different times is another thing that
is relatively new and that helps us a lot with xero trust
here's some more differences um it used to be that we would kind of assume that an ip address was a
geolocation we we would say if you're coming from this you know this ip address you're in this network
range we're going to assume you're in the office building we we've known for a long time that we can't do that we
know that i p addresses can be spoofed so if we don't know where they are from the
ip address how else can we figure this out well we have gps now
i remember in the mid 90s trying to play around with access based
with location-based access control and it didn't work very well because the gps receivers
were not as good and you had to hold them out the window and all that kind of stuff but we have gps now readily available
another thing that we're doing differently is we're also taking workloads and workplace devices into account not just
user driven devices but of industrial control systems iot
uh medical devices and so on workloads that are being used in either in the
private cloud or the public cloud again we're expanding beyond just users
and their own devices there are more secure enclaves and trusted computing
modules that we can leverage for some of these operations and surprise
users have been getting cranky with all of this authentication and the experience actually carries more
weight now so we are relying more on mobile we're having more users who are insisting
on being able to use the form factor that they're most comfortable with and usually these are your trickiest
users your your highest status users your c suite your professors your doctors or whatever
we're using more single sign-on which is great and we have emerging standards like web
off in web authentication and ctap 2 are leading us down the road to
something we've been hoping for for a long time and it looks like we might actually be able to accomplish it which
is passwordless now that's going to be a different webinar altogether but i'm here to say
that because of all of these things we are tightening up on the weaknesses around
credentials and we're adding more factors we're making them more flexible for the user experience
and passwordless is definitely going to be a big part of this
so you know what does this mean you might have already planned to use a zero trust
model in your organization or you might just have been caught by surprise by this flight diversion and you've been
throwing things in and trying to figure out what do you do now i'm here to tell you
that if you're doing one or more of the things on this list if you're inspecting
devices and their security state at authentication time if you're using mdm or if you're not if
you're able to use some of the other technologies to look at unmanaged devices
if you're using least privileged segmentation single sign-on if you're using
encryption everywhere and you know even if you have a reverse proxy already in operation
and if you're doing any or all of these regardless of the location
if you're even using them inside of your corporate network first of all you're giving your users a

the first one i like to call it uh is digital trust versus you know what what

it is not tied to any kind of ownership of control meaning it should not rely on the

most important part of digital trust is that it is ephemeral right which means that it should only be

um that you know zero trust is is kind of a it's a catchy term but it's

but there is another side to this which is the flip side of this coin right which is digital risk so

that this digital risk is assigned by matching what my risk tolerance is to the trust

separate the the assignment of risk in the assignment of trust they don't

and then your authentication systems in your verification systems are responsible for granting and
creating enough data points so that that level of credentialing or that level
of trust is achieved before you will be granted access to uh to that
to that particular resource so what that means is zero trust is

relies heavily on um a you know a concept called defense in depth
which means that it's not you know you just can't deploy one thing there's no silver bullet and just say
that it is it is zero trust so where do we start right so we should always start
with identification and authentication first rule right no unauthenticated packet touches the
wire so to authenticate you must identify otherwise what's going to happen is that

next we start looking at authorization this has two flavors one is at the web
